titleInfo.title: Snare the Signal in the Vision Jungle
titleInfo.subTitle: The Subfunctionalization of STX3 Ohnologs and Their Chaperone STXBP1B in Zebrafish Cone Vision

mods:mods.abstract: The vertebrate neural retina acts as a light detector, where photons are transduced into chemical and electrical signals at the brain. Phototransduction takes place in the photoreceptor cell outer segment (OS). Rods are responsible for dim light vision; cones are responsible for color vision and high spatial resolution. Visual information is transmitted from photoreceptor synapses to bipolar cells in the inner retina. The signal is encoded in the ribbon synapses of these two types of retinal neurons. Humans rely upon cone vision. Most mammalian models are nocturnal, and their retinas are rod-dominated. Zebrafish has emerged as a powerful model for studying gene function and neural development. Zebrafish is diurnal; cone out-number rods in twenty-to-one in larval retina. Behavior assays have shown that zebrafish are largely dependent on cone vision. My projects utilized zebrafish as genetic models to investigate the role of the soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor (SNARE) complex in cone and bipolar cells. The SNARE complex is a central membrane fusion machinery that is essential for synaptic transmission and membrane trafficking. Mutations in SNARE proteins have been implicated in microvillus inclusion disease (MVID) and a spectrum of neuronal developmental disorder such as encephalopathy and retina dystrophy. The t-SNARE protein syntaxin-3 (Stx3) and syntaxin-binding protein-1 (Stxbp1) are exclusively expressed in the photoreceptor and bipolar cell of the retina. Stx3 is crucial for photoreceptor development, rod OS morphogenesis, and synaptic vesicle exocytosis in ribbon synapses, whereas the role of Stxbp1 in the retina is largely unknown. Zebrafish (Danio rerio) have emerged as a powerful model organism for studying gene function. Whole genome duplication has resulted in two STX3 ohnologues in zebrafish, Stx3a (Chr.1) and Stx3b (Chr.14). Utilizing the CRISPR-Cas9 targeting system in the zebrafish model, my studies have demonstrated that Stx3a is specifically essential for cone development and cone-driven vision, whereas Stx3b ensures the signal transmission fidelity of bipolar cells. Our previous study found that Stxbp1b, a Stxbp1 ortholog in zebrafish, is essential for photoreceptor survival. I have shown that Stxbp1b is crucial for the protein stability of both Stx3 ohnologs in zebrafish. Collectively, my studies demonstrate that the subfunctionalization of Stx3 ohnologs in photoreceptors and bipolar cells, along with their chaperone Stxbp1b, are essential for cone vision in zebrafish.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Nystagmus, Photoreceptor degeneration, Stxbp1, Syntaxin-3 (Stx3), Zebrafish retina
James M. Fadool, Professor Directing Dissertation; Akash Gunjan, University Representative; Hengli Tang, Committee Member; Kenneth Taylor, Committee Member; Roberto Vincis, Committee Member.
